  "article_text": [
    "the goldman lie algebra is an algebra over the module generated by the set of free homotopy classes of loops on a surface , described by intersection and concatenation , that was introduced by william m. goldman in 1986 @xcite . + throughout this paper , let @xmath0 denote an oriented , genus @xmath1 surface with @xmath2 boundary components . denote @xmath3 to be the set of free homotopy classes of loops on @xmath0 , where we use @xmath4 when it is clear from the context which fixed surface we are discussing . recall the following .",
    "the set of free homotopy classes of loops on a surface @xmath0 is in one - to - one correspondence with conjugacy classes of @xmath5 .",
    "we can represent homotopy classes of loops by cyclically reduced words with letters the generators of the fundamental group . fix a surface @xmath0 and an orientation of @xmath0 .",
    "let @xmath6 .",
    "the * goldman bracket * of @xmath7 and @xmath8 is defined to be @xmath9=\\sum_{p \\in \\alpha \\cap \\beta } \\epsilon ( p ) \\alpha * _ p \\beta,\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where @xmath7 and @xmath8 intersect in transverse double points @xmath10 , and @xmath11 is the sign of the intersection , or @xmath12 if the ordered vectors in the tangent space to @xmath0 tangent to loop @xmath7 and @xmath8 match the orientation of the surface , and @xmath13 otherwise @xcite .     and",
    "@xmath14 on the torus with one boundary component.[fig : sigma11 ] ]    we compute @xmath15 $ ] on the surface @xmath16 .",
    "the loops represented by words @xmath17 and @xmath14 are shown in figure  [ fig : sigma11 ] , with intersection points @xmath18 and @xmath19 . at the intersection point",
    "@xmath18 , we smooth the intersection by creating a new loop , @xmath20 , by following the red loop @xmath17 in the direction of its orientation at @xmath18 , and when returning to @xmath18 , we now follow the blue loop @xmath14 in the direction of its orientation .",
    "when we return back to @xmath18 , we close the loop . at the intersection @xmath19",
    ", we do the same , and create the loop @xmath21 .",
    "we get that @xmath15=\\pm(aabb+abab)$ ] where the sign depends on the chosen orientation of @xmath16 . + (",
    "goldman ) the goldman bracket is well defined , skew - symmetric , and satisfies the jacobi identity @xcite . + we can extend the bracket linearly to @xmath22 $ ] ( or @xmath23 $ ] ) , the free module over @xmath24 ( or @xmath25 ) with basis @xmath4 , to get a bilinear map @xmath26 : { \\mathbb z}\\hat{\\pi}\\times { \\mathbb z}\\hat{\\pi } \\rightarrow { \\mathbb z}\\hat{\\pi}.\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] thus , @xmath27 is a lie algebra with bracket @xmath28 $ ] , which we call the _ goldman lie algebra _ , denoted by @xmath29 throughout the rest of this chapter .",
    "when it is unclear what the surface we are referring to , we use @xmath30",
    "so far , the center of the goldman lie algebra is known , but other parts of the structure is still unknown .",
    "the following theorems are results on the center of the goldman lie algebra for closed surfaces , and surfaces with boundary , respectively .",
    "( etingof ) the center of @xmath31 is spanned by the contractible loop @xcite .",
    "( kabiraj ) the center of @xmath30 is generated by peripheral loops @xcite + a question posed by chas @xcite is whether or not @xmath29 is finitely generated . in goldman s paper @xcite , he also introduces what is called the homological goldman lie algebra .",
    "this lie algebra is defined on intersection form on the first homology group of a surface .",
    "it is known that this lie algebra is indeed finitely generated @xcite , the ideals are known @xcite , and the center for the surface of infinite genus has been found @xcite .",
    "the closed torus is a special case as @xmath32 is finitely generated .",
    "recall that we can represent free homotopy classes of loops on @xmath33 by cyclically reduced words in two letters , @xmath34 and @xmath14 , and we can represent all homotopy classes of loops on the torus by the word @xmath35 for @xmath36 .",
    "the following theorem by chas says that the goldman bracket gives the intersection number of the free homotopy classes of loops as a coefficient of the new concatenated loop .",
    "[ prop : torusstructure ] ( chas @xcite ) the goldman bracket structure of @xmath37 is given by @xmath38=(il - jk)a^{i+k}b^{j+l}.\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] [ thm : torus]@xmath32 is finitely generated when considered as a lie algebra over @xmath25 .",

    "@xmath77&=-a^{-1},\\\\ [ a^{-1}b^{-1}+b+1,a]&=b^{-1}-ab,\\\\ [ a , b]&=ab.\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] @xmath32 as a lie algebra over @xmath25 is not nilpotent , nor solvable , since @xmath78 = \\mathfrak{g}_{\\sigma_{1,0}}$ ] .",
    "@xmath32 is not finitely generated as a lie algebra over @xmath79 .",

    "so @xmath87 , and @xmath88 , so @xmath89 , which is a contradiction .",
    "we conjecture that @xmath30 for @xmath90 and @xmath91 is not finitely generated . for the particular case for a punctured torus",
    ", the peripheral loop is given by a commutator word .",
    "we noticed in using chas program for computing the bracket seems to not generate a commutator word , nor products of commutators .",
    "this needs more work , but this would mean we have a set @xmath92 of infinitely many homotopy classes of loops that each can not be generated by any other homotopy classes of loops . [",

    "_ 64 , no . 4 , 1167 - 1190 ( 2013 ) n. kawazumi , y. kuno , k. toda , generators of the homological goldman lie algebra , _ osaka k. math _ , * 51 * , 665 - 671 , ( 2014 ) k. toda , the ideals of the homological goldman lie algebra , _ kodai math .",
    "j. _ 36 , no.2 , 189 - 196 , ( 2013 )"
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we consider the structure of the goldman lie algebra for the closed torus , and show that it is finitely generated over the rationals . </S>",
    "<S> we also consider other traditional lie algebra structures and determine that the goldman lie algebra for the torus is not nilpotent or solvable , and we compute the derived lie algebra . </S>"
  ]
}
